text:
It has indeed been discussed before, and generally evolves into a discussion as to the meaning of exposure.

But there are a couple of practical reasons in favour of the approach used:
1. many of us use strategies that look at runners individually and data leaking in from other runners would be confusing and upset those strategies
2. computationally, having to look at every runner's position to calculate the exposure for a given runner would be slow, and exponentially slower as the number of runners increases, for example fields of 150+ are common in golf
That said, the blotter also has a market_exposure method, which, while still not what you're looking for, does demonstrate how you could combine the individual selection exposures to produce alternative perspectives.

elements.text:

But there are a couple of practical reasons in favour of the approach used:
many of us use strategies that look at runners individually and data leaking in from other runners would be confusing and upset those strategies

computationally, having to look at every runner's position to calculate the exposure for a given runner would be slow, and exponentially slower as the number of runners increases, for example fields of 150+ are common in golf

That said, the blotter also has a market_exposure method, which, while still not what you're looking for, does demonstrate how you could combine the individual selection exposures to produce alternative perspectives.

root.text: Hi everyone! I'm fairly new to the automated betting world and would like to start by getting my hands on some of the historical data that betfair supplies at <https://historicdata.betfair.com/#/home>. Problem is that I live in Sweden and this service is not accessible for us swedes... Does anyone know an alternate way to get access to historical data? Thanks in advance! :raised_hands:

elements.text: Hi everyone! I'm fairly new to the automated betting world and would like to start by getting my hands on some of the historical data that betfair supplies at
. Problem is that I live in Sweden and this service is not accessible for us swedes... Does anyone know an alternate way to get access to historical data? Thanks in advance!

text: did you find any solution for this? I got greyhound data from 2013 and would like to get the odds 1min or 30sec before the scheduled jump

elements.text: did you find any solution for this? I got greyhound data from 2013 and would like to get the odds 1min or 30sec before the scheduled jump

text:
<@U065R0MLLBB> It's not clear to which question you're looking for a solution: obtaining historical data in Sweden, or filtering streams on a time range.

If it's the Swedish thing, we've seen other questions about Betfair-related things happening differently in Sweden, so there are likely to be legal, regulatory or licensing issues that preclude an easy answer.

If it's streaming with a time range - that's not how Betfair streams work. The accepted solution is the one alluded to by <@U04NWADNCFR>, namely record all the data, persist to a file and then stream the through Flumine setting the <https://betcode-org.github.io/flumine/quickstart/#listener-kwargs|listener kwargs> to do the filtering for you.

If it's streaming with a time range - that's not how Betfair streams work. The accepted solution is the one alluded to by

listener kwargs

text:
hi guys, I was wondering if anyone would be happy to share a rough data workflow? It’s something I'm struggling with a bit. For example, when saving CSVs for analysis are people saving the whole timeseries - isn’t that sometimes difficult to handle memory-wise in a notebook? Or do people upsample the timeseries? How do you guys usually structure the greyhounds/horses data for more efficient loading in notebooks - by market, or one big file which contains everything?
At the moment, since I trade greyhounds, I have 1 big CSV per month (all markets) with the whole timeseries starting at 2 minutes before, but I am finding this a bit messy.

elements.text:

How do you guys usually structure the greyhounds/horses data for more efficient loading in notebooks - by market, or one big file which contains everything?
At the moment, since I trade greyhounds, I have 1 big CSV per month (all markets) with the whole timeseries starting at 2 minutes before, but I am finding this a bit messy.

text: Hi. Try to focus on the specfic things you're investigating. You only need the whole stream for high frequency stuff and that can't really be explored in CSVs, you'd use a backtest for that. But try using a backtest (with no actually betting strategy, just a blitz through the data)  as a means of logging if the data doesn't directly store what you need, or to extract at a lower frequncy, or just in certain conditions.  Also work on just a subset of your data warehouse and then test against the remaining data to safeguard against backfitting and to speed up your analysis.

elements.text: Hi. Try to focus on the specfic things you're investigating. But try using a backtest (with no actually betting strategy, just a blitz through the data)  as a means of logging if the data doesn't directly store what you need, or to extract at a lower frequncy, or just in certain conditions.  Also work on just a subset of your data warehouse and then test against the remaining data to safeguard against backfitting and to speed up your analysis.

text: Maybe 1s <@U060V0QKPLZ>? But totally depends what you want to do with it. There's too many styles and methods of trading to be prescriptive. And you can always re-extract differently for different ideas.  But start simple and only add complexity/time/effort if an idea is standing up.

text:
Suppose I have two sets of probability estimates for a few thousand horse races. I also have the race results.

How can I determine which set of estimates is better?

text: Depends what you want them to be better for, if you’re betting then you probably need prices but if you just want an accurate probability model I would use both and stick in a logistic regression

text: Is it all selections or not.  If a strategy selects runners then the assumption that a randomly seleted sample will have an overall 0ev BSP goes out of the window as it's no longer random.

elements.text: Is it all selections or not.  If a strategy selects runners then the assumption that a randomly seleted sample will have an overall 0ev BSP goes out of the window as it's no longer random.
